definitions: deliberately avoid doing something or hold yourself back from an action or behavior
examples: Please refrain from smoking inside the hospital building
She had to refrain from laughing during the serious meeting

definitions: give new strength or energy to something or someone by making it fresh again
update or renew information in a computer system or display
examples: A cold drink will refresh you after your long walk
The cool breeze refreshed everyone at the outdoor wedding
Click the button to refresh the webpage for new content
You need to refresh your browser to see the changes

definitions: put more fuel into a vehicle or aircraft to continue its journey
examples: The plane needs to refuel before crossing the Pacific Ocean
We stopped at the gas station to refuel the car

definitions: return money to someone who paid for something they are returning or not satisfied with
examples: The store will refund your purchase within thirty days
They refunded my ticket when the concert was cancelled

definitions: clean and decorate a building or room to make it more attractive and useful again
examples: They plan to refurbish the old theater downtown this summer
The company refurbished all their office computers with new parts

definitions: prove that a statement or theory is wrong by giving evidence or logical arguments
examples: The scientist refuted the old theory with her new research
He tried to refute the accusations against him in court

definitions: get back something you had before but lost such as strength health or control
examples: She worked hard to regain her strength after the illness
The team needs to regain their confidence after losing three games

definitions: grow new tissue or parts to replace what was damaged or lost
bring new life energy or growth to something that was declining
examples: Some lizards can regenerate their tails when they lose them
Starfish can regenerate lost arms over several months
The city hopes to regenerate the abandoned industrial district
Forest fires help regenerate the ecosystem with new plant growth

definitions: organize or control something in a very strict way with rigid rules and discipline
examples: The coach regimented every minute of the team's practice schedule
Military schools regiment their students' daily activities very strictly

definitions: come together again as a group after being separated or scattered
reorganize yourself mentally or physically after a setback to try again
examples: The scattered soldiers regrouped at the meeting point
The team regrouped after halftime to discuss new strategies
After failing the first attempt we need to regroup and try differently
She took a moment to regroup before making another presentation

definitions: grow back again after being cut damaged or lost especially for living tissue
examples: Hair will regrow after chemotherapy treatment ends for most patients
The farmer let the field regrow naturally after the harvest

definitions: help someone recover their health or normal life through training and therapy after illness or imprisonment
restore the good reputation of someone or something that was previously criticized
examples: The center helps rehabilitate injured athletes back to full fitness
Programs to rehabilitate prisoners aim to reduce repeat offenses
The company worked hard to rehabilitate its image after the scandal
The mayor promised to rehabilitate the city's damaged reputation

definitions: practice a play musical performance or speech before presenting it to an audience
examples: The actors rehearse every evening before opening night
She rehearsed her wedding speech many times to feel confident

definitions: rule as a king or queen over a country or territory
be the most obvious or powerful feature in a particular situation
examples: Queen Elizabeth II reigned over Britain for seventy years
The emperor reigned during a time of great prosperity
Chaos reigned in the streets after the power outage
Peace finally reigned after years of conflict ended

definitions: pay back money to someone who has spent it for you or your organization
examples: The company will reimburse your travel expenses for the conference
Please keep all receipts so we can reimburse you later

definitions: control a horse by pulling on leather straps attached to its head
control or limit something that has too much freedom or power
examples: She learned to rein her horse smoothly around the track
The rider had to rein the horse to stop it running
The government needs to rein in spending before the deficit grows
Parents should rein in their children's screen time

definitions: give someone back their previous job or position after they had lost it
examples: The court ordered the company to reinstate the fired employee
They voted to reinstate him as team captain after his suspension

definitions: help someone become part of society or a group again after being away or excluded
examples: Programs help reintegrate veterans into civilian life after military service
The school works to reintegrate students who have been suspended

definitions: explain or understand something in a new or different way from how it was understood before
examples: Modern directors often reinterpret classic plays for contemporary audiences
Historians reinterpret past events based on newly discovered documents

definitions: bring something back into use or existence after it had been removed or had disappeared
examples: Scientists hope to reintroduce wolves to their former habitats
The school plans to reintroduce art classes next semester

definitions: create something again in a completely new way as if it never existed before
change yourself or something so completely that you seem like someone or something entirely new
examples: You don't need to reinvent the wheel just use existing solutions
Each generation seems to reinvent fashion trends from the past
After losing her job she decided to reinvent herself as an artist
The company had to reinvent its business model to survive

definitions: give new energy strength or enthusiasm to something that had become weak or boring
examples: The new coach hopes to reinvigorate the struggling team
Fresh ideas can reinvigorate a stale business strategy

definitions: publish or produce something again especially a book record or official document
examples: The publisher decided to reissue the classic novel with new illustrations
The government will reissue passports that were lost in the fire

definitions: say something again or repeatedly to emphasize it or make it very clear
examples: Let me reiterate the importance of arriving on time tomorrow
The teacher had to reiterate the instructions several times

definitions: feel or show great joy or happiness about something especially through celebration
examples: The whole town rejoiced when their team won the championship
Parents rejoice at seeing their children succeed in life

definitions: join a group or organization again after leaving it or being away from it
examples: She plans to rejoin the company after her maternity leave
He will rejoin his teammates after recovering from his injury

definitions: make someone or something look or feel younger fresher or more lively
examples: A good vacation can rejuvenate your mind and body
The spa treatment is designed to rejuvenate aging skin

definitions: light a fire again after it has gone out
make a feeling or relationship become strong again after it had weakened
examples: He used dry leaves to rekindle the campfire
We need to rekindle the fire before it gets too cold
They hope to rekindle their friendship after years apart
The old photos rekindled memories of their childhood together

definitions: become ill again after a period of improvement in health
return to a previous bad behavior or addiction after trying to stop
examples: The patient relapsed after stopping her medication too soon
He relapsed into fever after seeming to recover
Many smokers relapse within the first month of quitting
She relapsed into drinking after six months of sobriety

definitions: receive and pass on information or a message to someone else
receive and transmit an electronic signal to extend its range
examples: Please relay this message to everyone who couldn't attend the meeting
The secretary will relay your concerns to the manager
Satellites relay television signals across vast distances
The antenna relays radio signals to remote areas

definitions: move someone or something to a lower or less important position rank or status
examples: The team was relegated to a lower division after losing
Poor sales relegated the product to discount stores only

definitions: become less severe harsh or strict often by showing mercy or sympathy
examples: The storm finally relented after three days of heavy rain
Her parents relented and let her go to the party

definitions: voluntarily give up something you own or control such as power rights or possessions
examples: The CEO refused to relinquish control of the company
She had to relinquish her dream of becoming a doctor

definitions: enjoy something very much and take great pleasure or satisfaction in it
examples: He relished every moment of his retirement after forty years
She relished the opportunity to prove her critics wrong

definitions: experience something again in your mind by remembering it very clearly and vividly
examples: Looking at old photos made her relive her wedding day
Veterans sometimes relive traumatic events through nightmares

definitions: put more ammunition into a weapon or more material into a device
examples: The soldier had to reload his rifle during the battle
You need to reload the printer with paper before continuing

definitions: move to a new place and establish your home or business there
examples: The company decided to relocate its headquarters to Texas
Many families relocate for better job opportunities

definitions: sell books or other goods at a reduced price because they have not sold
examples: The bookstore will remainder old inventory at half price
Publishers often remainder books that didn't sell well initially

definitions: make something again or differently especially a movie or song in a new version
examples: Hollywood loves to remake classic films with modern actors
She decided to remake the dress in a different color

definitions: send a prisoner back into custody to wait for trial or further investigation
examples: The judge decided to remand the suspect until the trial
He was remanded in custody for two weeks pending investigation

definitions: marry someone again after being divorced or after your spouse has died
examples: She chose to remarry five years after her husband's death
Statistics show many divorced people remarry within three years

definitions: correct or improve a bad or unsatisfactory situation or cure an illness
examples: The government promised to remedy the housing shortage quickly
This medicine should remedy your headache within an hour

definitions: think or talk about pleasant events from the past with enjoyment and nostalgia
examples: The old friends loved to reminisce about their college days
Grandparents often reminisce about how different life was before

definitions: send money as payment especially to a distant place or person
cancel or reduce a debt punishment or other obligation
examples: Please remit payment within thirty days of receiving this invoice
Workers remit money to their families in other countries
The governor decided to remit the prisoner's sentence
The court may remit the fine due to financial hardship

definitions: change the structure or design of a building room or vehicle to improve it
examples: They plan to remodel their kitchen with modern appliances
The old factory was remodeled into luxury apartments

definitions: get back on a horse bicycle or other vehicle after getting off
organize and present a theatrical production or exhibition again
examples: The rider quickly remounted after falling from her horse
He had to remount his bike after fixing the chain
The theater company will remount the popular play next season
They decided to remount the art exhibition due to demand

definitions: give a new name to someone or something that already has a name
examples: They voted to rename the street after the civil rights leader
The company will rename itself to reflect its new direction

definitions: abandon your religious political or personal beliefs and loyalties to join an opposing group
examples: The soldier chose to renegade and join the rebel forces
Several members threatened to renegade from the political party
